item.title: Reacting is Easier
item.description:
It’s easier to let other people occupy my time. React to their needs.
It feels productive to make progress for others. To see that I can help them.
Responding to emails, attending meetings, looking at Slack alerts.

So I sit down to do some deep work: some heavy thought about big projects. And I find myself checking my email and looking for Slack alerts. Secretly hoping someone else will block out the next hour for me, so that I don’t have to drive forward my own thoughts. Because it’s hard to do that. It hurts to do that. I feel incompetent and inadequate when I do that.

But letting this happen leads to a busy, ostensibly productive life of doing very little. But as a declaration of focus, let me say that I will choose my time, and explicitly accept that it will be more difficult to do this. I will have to let others down, and I will likely fail quite a bit. But it’s better than the alternative.

Now let’s get started on some of those future failing ideas.

item.title: Rain on Leaves
item.description:
Rain began to beat down on me yesterday morning.

I was trail running.
I woke up before the sun.
My mind was clear.
I was doing my part.

But the rain beat down on my path. It began to pour, and I could hear the orchestra of the raining forest: rain on leaves.

And when I think about the sound of rain on leaves, I think of relaxation. I imagine most people do. It’s used in spas and healing centers, white noise machines and concentration soundtracks.

But I was wet, and my fingers were numb. It wasn’t a spa or a sleep aid. It was uncomfortable. The rain on the leaves was uncomfortable. I had every reason to feel uncomfortable, to put my mind in a state of discomfort and feel sorry for my bad luck.

I had every reason to feel sorry for my unfortunate circumstances.

Or.
I could listen to the rain on the leaves.

item.title: Tao of Running - Everything Balances
item.description:
While reading the Tao Te Ching, I found that certain chapters connect very well with running. In order to further connect with these chapters myself, I “translated” them into a form that directly connects with running, which is a fundamental part of my life.

This is from Chapter 2 of the Tao Te Ching; translated by Stephen Mitchell:

Seeing some runs as beautiful
makes other runs ugly
Seeing some runs as good
makes other runs bad

Running and non-running create each other
Difficult and easy runs support each other
Long and short runs define each other
A runner’s highs and lows depend on each other
The time before and after running follow each other

Therefore the Master
runs without doing anything
and instructs without saying anything
Things arise and she lets them come
Things disappear and she lets them go
She has ability without possessing it
runs without expectation

When her run is finished, she forgets it
that is why it lasts forever
